title: Shah-Armens
text:
The Shah-Armens (lit. 'Kings of Armenia', ), also known as Ahlatshahs (lit. 'Rulers of Ahlat', ), was a 11th- and 12th-century Turcoman <a href="Anatolian%20beylik">beylik</a> founded after the <a href="Battle%20of%20Manzikert">Battle of Manzikert</a> (1071) and centred in <a href="Ahlat">Ahlat</a> on the northwestern shore of the <a href="Lake%20Van">Lake Van</a>. This region comprised most of modern-day <a href="Bitlis%20Province">Bitlis</a> and <a href="Van%20Province">Van</a>, and parts of <a href="Mu%C5%9F%20Province">Muş</a> provinces.
The dynasty is sometimes also called "Sökmenli" in reference to the founder of the principality, <a href="S%C3%B6kmen%20el-Kutb%C3%AE">Sökmen el-Kutbî</a>, literally "Sökmen the Slave", one of the commanders of the <a href="Seljuq%20dynasty">Great Seljuq</a> <a href="Alp%20Arslan">Alp Arslan</a>. The Ahlatshah Sökmenli should not be confused with the <a href="Artuqid">Artuqid</a> branch of Sökmenli, which ruled in <a href="Hasankeyf">Hasankeyf</a> during approximately the same period.
Another title Sökmen and his descendants assumed, as heirs to the local <a href="Armenians">Armenian</a> princes according to <a href="Clifford%20Edmund%20Bosworth">Clifford Edmund Bosworth</a>, was the Persian title "Shah-i Arman" ("Shah of Armenia"), often rendered as "Ermenshahs". This dynastic name, which the Turkmen rulers adopted, was established through the "ethnic make-up and political history" of the region they ruled, which was primarily Armenian.
The Beylik was founded by the Turkmen <a href="ghilman">slave commander</a> Sökmen who took over Ahlat ("Khliat" or "Khilat") in 1100. Ahlatshahs were closely tied to Great Seljuq institutions, although they also followed independent policies like the wars against <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Georgia">Georgia</a> in alliance with their neighbours to the north, the <a href="Saltukids">Saltukids</a>. They also acquired links with the branch of the <a href="Artuqid%20dynasty">Artuqid dynasty</a> based in Meyyafarikin (now <a href="Silvan%2C%20Turkey">Silvan</a>), becoming part of a nexus of Turkmen principalities in <a href="Upper%20Mesopotamia">Upper Mesopotamia</a> and Eastern Anatolia.
The Ahlatshahs reached their brightest period under the fifty-seven-year reign of Sökmen II (1128–1185). He was married to a female relative (daughter or sister) of the Saltukid ruler <a href="Saltuk%20II">Saltuk II</a>. Since Sökmen II was childless, the "beylik" was seized by a series of slave commanders after his death. In 1207, the "beylik" was taken over by the <a href="Ayyubids">Ayyubids</a>, who had long coveted Ahlat. The Ayyubids had come to the city at the invitation of people of Ahlat after the last Sökmenli ruler was killed by Tuğrulshah, the ruler ("melik") of <a href="Erzurum">Erzurum</a> on behalf of the <a href="Sultanate%20of%20R%C3%BBm">Sultanate of Rûm</a> and brother of Sultan <a href="Kayqubad%20I">Kayqubad I</a>.
The Ahlatshahs left a large number of historic <a href="Headstone">tombstones</a> in and around the city of <a href="Ahlat">Ahlat</a>. Local administrators are currently trying to have the tombstones included in <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="World%20Heritage%20List">World Heritage List</a>, where they are currently listed tentatively.
